title: iSignthis or bust for LHC's Marcus Hughes
text:
Well, isn’t boutique Sydney hedge fund LHC Capital leading with its chin?!

The absolute return manager’s principals Marcus Hughes and Stephen “Sheikh” Aboud are touting the performance of their high conviction fund (up 10.54 per cent in the three months to September 30) while its largest position, iSignthis, remains suspended from trading at the behest of the Australian Securities Exchange and the Australian Securities and Investments Commission.

“We remain comfortable with our holding in the business,” they wrote their fund investors. And were they not, there isn’t a thing they could do about it.

These boys must have cast-iron stomachs and audacity on tap because the aforementioned 10.5 per cent return (and the 27.95 per cent return for calendar 2019) relies on their 89.45 million iSignthis shares each being worth their September 30 closing price of 93.5¢. A heroic assumption!

Hughes is an alumnus of Caledonia Investments (where Will Vicars and Mike Messara are balls deep in US pets Zillow, Grubhub and the Stars Group), so he’s no stranger to a wild swing for the fences. Even still, how could a manager whose tagline is “capital preservation” allocate nearly a quarter of its portfolio to a single stock, let alone a dicey one that now may well be a zero?

Or an investment house with “a strong capability in risk management with a clear aim of producing absolute returns that are uncorrelated to general market conditions”? That uncorrelated bit looks true, at least – the market is up, while they’ve apparently incinerated 21.75 per cent of funds under management.
description: How could an asset manager whose tagline is “capital preservation” allocate nearly a quarter of its $440 million portfolio to a single stock?
